Doron Levin Writing – original draft Materials and Applied Chemistry Chief Scientist, ExxonMobil Technology and Engineering, 1545 US 22 East, Annandale, NJ 08801, United States Materials and Applied Chemistry Chief Scientist ExxonMobil Technology and Engineering 1545 US 22 East Annandale NJ 08801 United States Materials and Applied Chemistry Chief Scientist, ExxonMobil Technology and Engineering, 1545 US 22 East, Annandale, NJ 08801 According to the International Energy Forum [1], the third energy transition is underway. However, it will differ in consequences from the first and second energy transitions which transformed the way that mankind uses energy. The third energy transition is primarily additive to the energy resource base rather than a substantial replacement for existing sources of energy. The world needs a lot of energy, approximately 1 quadrillion BTUs (= 1.055 exajoules) every 14.6 h, and supplying that energy in a way that meets the world’s needs and lowers emissions is the key challenge facing society. While the second energy transition was in part enabled by and dependent on advances in catalysis, it is unclear what the impact of catalysis will be on the third energy transition which is driven primarily by the movement of electrons rather than transformation of molecules. This perspective article attempts to provide some thoughts and insights in addressing this question. Graphical Abstract Keywords Energy transition Catalysis Metals Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction For thousands of years, an average human’s existence was short, brutal and harsh. The lack of access to the technology we take for granted today, as well as the lack of energy needed to support a modern lifestyle made life a struggle for our ancestors. Until approximately the 18th century, humans generally relied on the contraction of a muscle fiber, whether human or animal, to generate the force needed to change something in one’s environment. The energy to generate this force comes from the breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) that is produced by the mitochondria in muscle cells through a process called oxidative phosphorylation [2]. The energy to create ATP comes from food sources, generally carbohydrates, fats and proteins, that humans and animals consume. Until approximately the 18th century, the fuel used to keep us warm, provide light in the dark and cook our food came from the burning of biomass such as wood, peat, natural oils (e.g. olive oil, nut oils, fish oil, whale oil), natural waxes (e.g. beeswax) and animal dung. To move around, humans walked with their feet, rode on an animal such as a horse, ox, camel or donkey, or relied on the wind to push a sail that allowed for slow exploration with limited maneuverability across unpredictable seas. Catalysis was not understood and played no role as an enabler for mankind to that point. 1.1 First energy transition The first energy transition took place starting in the 18th century with the development of the steam engine. In 1712, an Englishman, Thomas Newcomen, developed a commercial steam engine which was significantly improved upon by James Watt in 1765 [3]. In a steam engine, pressurized steam generated by the boiling of water expands in a cylinder and exerts a force on a piston, enabling the heat energy to be converted to work. The energy to generate this force comes from the oxidative combustion of a fuel to boil the water and generate steam where the combustion products are external to the working fluid. The dominant fuel source for steam engines of the 18th and 19th centuries was coal given its availability and higher energy density than wood. Coal was also used to keep humans warm and cook our food. The burning of biomass and natural oils, e.g. whale oil, continued to provide light into the 19th century when illumination by burning of gas (e.g. methane, ethane, propane, etc.) became more widespread. To move around, humans continued to walk or ride an animal, but the availability of steam engines allowed for the development of steam locomotives and steam ships, giving mankind the ability to cross continents and oceans, significantly expanding the environment that one could explore. Catalysis was not well understood but started to play a minor role in the cleanup of coal gas used for illumination. 1.2 Second energy transition The second energy transition took place starting in the 19th century with the development of the internal combustion engine (ICE). While the first successful gas engine was developed by the Belgian French engineer Étienne Lenoir in 1859, it took the refinements introduced by the German inventor Nikolaus Otto in 1878 to make the gas engine a commercial success [4]. The first liquid fueled ICE engine was invented by the American George Brayton in 1872, and the first reliable two-stroke gasoline engine was patented by Karl Benz in 1879 [5]. In the internal combustion engine, the expansion of high-temperature and high-pressure gases apply a force to some component of the engine (piston, turbine blade, etc.), enabling the chemical energy of the fuel to be converted to kinetic energy of the engine. The energy to produce this force comes from the oxidation of a fuel where the combustion products are the working fluid. The dominant fuel source for IC engines are liquid hydrocarbons derived from crude oil, typically gasoline, jet and diesel fuels. The development of the oil industry following the discovery by Edwin L. Drake in Titusville, Pennsylvania in 1859 was driven initially by the demand for kerosene as an illuminating fuel for lamps which displaced natural oils and waxes. By the end of the 19th century, the internal combustion engine was displacing the steam engine as mankind’s preferred technology for generating force and this led to the development of gasoline powered automobiles, diesel powered trucks and locomotives, bunker oil powered ships and jet fuel powered airplanes which enabled us to travel the world. It is during this second energy transition that catalysis came into its own as a science and was a fundamental enabler for the production of abundant, reliable, clean-burning fuels that modern life depends on. There are many catalytic processes that played a key role in the production of fuels underpinning the second energy transition. In the late 19th century, oil refining was primarily based on separation via distillation of the targeted streams, primarily middle distillates (kerosene). Conversion reactions at oil refineries were introduced after the discovery of thermal cracking in 1913 [6]. Prior to the introduction of catalytic cracking in the 1930s, production of fuels via catalytic routes was achieved via the discovery of the methanol synthesis pathway from syngas in 1923 by Mittasch and Pier at BASF [7] and the production of hydrocarbons via CO hydrogenation by Fischer and Tropsch at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Coal Research [8]. In 1937, catalytic cracking developed by Houdry was commercialized by Socony-Vacuum (later Mobil Oil) and Sun Company (later Sunoco, Inc.) which enabled the production of 100 octane aviation gasoline just prior to World War II [9]. In the 1940s, growing molecular weight of light olefins via oligomerization was discovered by Ipatieff at Universal Oil Products [10] and growing molecular weight via alkylation with isobutane using HF/H2SO4 was discovered by Frey at Phillips Petroleum Company [11], both processes leading to huge growth in the availability of high-octane gasoline. In addition, catalytic reforming was developed by Haensel at Universal Oil Products in the late 1940s, allowing for the upgrading of low octane paraffins into isoparaffins and the production of reformate [12]. The 1950s brought the development of hydrotreating, initially driven by the need to protect noble metal catalytic reforming processes as well as the availability of by-product hydrogen from said processes, which improved the properties of fuels. The first modern hydrocracking unit went on-stream in 1959 at Standard Oil of California which led to rapid growth in capacity and the availability of fuels. In addition to increases in availability of fuels, significant reductions in the emissions of sulfur and nitrogen containing molecules were achieved by the development of higher activity hydrotreating catalysts to ensure that stricter environmental regulations could be met. The development of catalytic converters for automobiles also led to an improvement in air quality. The net effect of all these catalytic processes developed in support of the second energy transition was to shift the molecules found in crude oil to meet the market demand, as shown in Fig. 1. 1.3 Third energy transition The third energy transition, currently underway, started in the 21st century with the development of multiple technologies such as the Li ion battery, rare earth magnets, and high voltage semiconductors. In an electric motor, force is generated by the flow of electric current through a magnetic field, with electricity being the “fuel” generating the force. Electricity can be generated by converting the kinetic energy of a moving fluid such as steam, air, or water into mechanical rotation of a turbine connected to a generator. Steam can be generated by the boiling of water through heating, with the energy to heat the water supplied by the combustion of fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas) as in the 1st and 2nd energy transitions or through heat generated by a nuclear reactor. The movement of air as wind or water through a dam can generate the force required to rotate a turbine, generating electricity. Electricity is also the dominant supplier of the energy humans use to cook our food and provide light. To move around, humans continue to rely on automobiles (of which an increasing share are electric), trains, ships and airplanes, but with a wider variety of feedstocks providing the energy needed to make then run, such as methanol and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from hydrotreated oils. Returning to the question of the title, is catalysis an enabler for the third energy transition? Given that many believe this energy transition will be primarily driven by increased electricity use, what role will catalysis play and what role can catalysis play? 2 The world’s need for energy Energy use and living standards go hand in hand. As shown in Fig. 2, there is a strong correlation between higher energy use and human prosperity, as measured by the UN Human Development Index (HDI) [13]. The HDI is a summary measure of three key dimensions, namely life expectancy at birth, knowledge (as indicated by expected years of schooling) and a decent standard of living (as indicated by Gross National Income per capita.) Access to more energy allows people to improve their living standards, own more labor-saving appliances, travel more, heat and cool their homes, and access better medical facilities and equipment, leading to a higher quality of life. The UN data also show that the reverse is true – a lack of access to affordable, reliable energy lowers living standards. ExxonMobil’s Global Outlook estimates that the “modern energy minimum” is 50 million British Thermal Units (50 MMBTU) per capita at which level a country can provide universal access to clean cooking fuels, electricity and eliminate extreme poverty [14]. Global energy demand is expected to grow by 15 % by 2050, exceeding 660 quadrillion BTUs, as shown in Fig. 3. The bulk of the increase in energy demand will go toward meeting the higher living standards of the growing populations in the developing world. In the developed world, improvements in energy efficiency, for example better insulation, more efficient appliances, smarter homes, etc., will lead to a decline of ∼10 % in energy use [14]. However, this decrease in energy demand could be tempered by increased energy needs for data centers, especially driven by increased application of energy-hungry cryptocurrency mining and Artificial Intelligence (AI) [15]. For 2025, world energy demand is expected to be ∼600 quadrillion BTUs [14], equivalent to 1.64 quadrillion BTUs every day. This translates to 1 quadrillion BTUs (1015 BTUs = 1.055 exajoules (1.055 ×1018 J)) every 14.6 h. To put this in perspective, one quadrillion BTUs is the energy content of 293 terawatt-hours of electricity or ∼175 million barrels of oil. Using 24” (610 mm) diameter oil barrels stacked edge to edge, one would circumnavigate the earth at the equator (24,901 miles or 40,075 km) 2.66 times to reach 175 million barrels. The world needs a lot of energy, so the question is how we provide the energy that the world needs AND do so in a way that lowers emissions. Solving this “AND” equation will require innovative solutions, including those where catalysis can play a key role. The 2023 global energy mix is shown in Fig. 4 as well as the energy mix for three different projections in 2050 [14]. ExxonMobil’s Global Outlook for 2050 shows that the largest change in the world’s energy mix will come from significant increases in non-biomass renewables (fourfold increase in wind and solar) and a large reduction in coal as it gets displaced with lower emission sources for energy production. The Global Outlook is broadly consistent with the International Energy Agency “Stated Energy Policies Scenario” (STEPS) which reflects a sector-by-sector assessment of current policy in place or announced by governments around the world [16]. The last projection shown in Fig. 4 is a Paris-aligned scenario which is an average of 311 scenarios in the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) database with a 67 % likelihood of limiting peak warming to below 2°C throughout the 21st century. Under this projection, non-biomass renewables play a larger role, generating an average of ∼30 % of the world’s global energy needs, with a range spanning 9–59 %. Under all 2050 projections shown in Fig. 4, oil and gas will continue to play a role in meeting the world’s energy needs due to the fact that these hydrocarbons are energy dense, easily transportable, affordable and readily available. The refining and chemical industry will continue to rely on the catalytic technologies developed during the second energy transition to convert the molecules in crude oil and natural gas into the products that society needs to meet our energy needs. The growth in contributions to the world’s energy mix may come from primarily non-catalytic sources including nuclear, hydro, wind, solar and geothermal. Given this projection, where can catalysis play a role in the third energy transition? 3 Potential areas where catalysis can impact the third energy transition As discussed in Section 1.3, electrification is a key driver in the third energy transition. However, unlike for personal light-duty transportation, electrification is ill-suited for commercial heavy-duty transportation and industrial applications. Energy use must increase by 2050 to support a larger population and economic growth, and fossil fuels remain the most effective way to produce the enormous amounts of energy needed to support commercial transportation, manufacturing and industrial production. An important aspect of the third energy transition will be the decarbonization (i.e. lowering the CO2 footprint) of these economic sectors, which account for 40 % of all CO2 emissions today [14]. As shown in Fig. 5, carbon capture and storage, hydrogen-based fuel and biofuels will all need to grow dramatically in support of the goals of the third energy transition. 3.1 Carbon capture, utilization, and sequestration (CCUS) Carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) will be important to achieve society’s goal in reducing energy-related emissions. ExxonMobil’s Global Outlook projects that CO2 emissions will decline by 25 % by 2050 [14] but more will be needed to reach the emission reduction levels needed to keep global temperature increases below 2°C. Carbon capture and storage will play an important role in reaching these goals but will require scaling up at an unprecedented 185 times faster than its historical pace between now and 2050 [14]. Global opportunities for sequestration are quite large, but also very country and region specific. While CCS is not a catalytic technology, it is possible that some of the amorphous and microporous supports developed for catalysts will play a role in supporting molecules such as amines that are effective for capturing CO2. A bigger question for catalysis is the role that novel catalytic technologies can play in the conversion of CO2 into commodity products or materials, referred to as CO2 utilization (CCU). There are three broad categories of reactions that utilize CO2, namely carbonation (non-catalytic formation of inorganic carbonates), addition (condensation reactions with highly energetic co-reactants targeting small volume chemicals) and reduction (energy intensive processes using H2 targeting large volume fuels.) The latter process is indeed an area of active interest in the catalysis community, especially with respect to electrochemical reduction of CO2, as shown in Fig. 6. Since this perspective article is focused primarily on the provision of energy, CO2 carbonation to inorganic carbonates and addition reactions to chemicals will not be discussed further. CO2 utilization via the reduction pathway comes with multiple challenges to ensure environmental benefits as well as profitability. These pathways still require large amounts of energy and concentrated sources of CO2. These challenges are complex and become magnified with scale. Renewable electricity is a valuable resource and it will not be cheap or infinitely available. Competition for renewable electrons by companies able to efficiently monetize such electrons, e.g. data centers such as Amazon Web Services, Meta, Google, etc. will make it challenging to source such electrons to transport CO2 thermodynamically uphill. While typically not a focus for members of the academic catalysis community doing research in the area of CO2 utilization, it should be understood that detailed LCA/TEA analyses would likely show that the majority of research paths currently being explored in academic and national labs would fail to meet criteria for consideration for scale-up by industry when compared to next best alternatives. Consider the production of renewable fuels of non-biologic origin (RFNBO) or e-fuels, in this case a diesel, via commercially available Fischer-Tropsch chemistry from syngas, where the CO is produced via reverse water gas shift from CO2 and H2 is produced via water electrolysis as shown in Fig. 7. If we assume hexadecane (C16H34) as a representative diesel molecule, the overall equations to represent the synthesis outlined in Fig. 7 is shown below: (1) Water splitting: 49 H2O → 49 H2 + 24.5O2 (2) RWGS chemistry:16 CO2 + 16 H2 → 16 CO + 16 H2O (3) F-T chemistry:16 CO + 33 H2 → C16H34 + 16 H2O (4) Overall:16 CO2 + 17 H2O → C16H34 + 24.5 O2 The Gibbs Free Energy for the electrolysis of water is + 237 kJ/mol which gives a standard cell potential of −1.23 V (a negative voltage implies that current is needed to get the reaction to occur) [17]. However, to get reasonable current densities, an overpotential of 0.44 V is required [18], bringing the energy required to produce one mole of hydrogen from a cell operating at −1.67 V to 322 kJ. For this analysis, additional energy required to compress the hydrogen will be ignored. To convert 1 million tons of CO2 per annum (1 MTA) would therefore require 6.2 TWh of electricity just to split the water required in Eq. 1. This would generate ∼7.2 kbd of diesel. The US diesel demand in 2023 averaged 3.88 million barrels per day [19]. Therefore, 7.2 kbd represents 0.2 % of the average US diesel demand. To make 10 % of the average 2023 US diesel demand via e-fuels would therefore require 5.4 GT of CO2 which would need 335.5 TWh of electricity just to produce the hydrogen required via electrolysis. According to US Energy Information Administration [20], the United States had the capacity to generate 774.8 TWh of electricity from nuclear reactors in 2023. In other words, the United States would need to use 43 % of its installed nuclear generating capacity to generate the electrons to make the hydrogen needed to produce 10 % of the US diesel demand as e-fuel. Making 23 % of the US diesel demand as e-fuel would require 100 % of the installed nuclear generating capacity. This is just the energy needed for the hydrolysis of water and does not include all the other energy inputs needed to make the finished fuel. This would not leave a renewable electron left over to charge an electric vehicle or a mobile phone, provide light and heat in your home, or provide energy to cook your food. The catalysis community would be well served to understand this and direct its research accordingly. 3.2 Hydrogen-based fuel As shown in Fig. 5, ExxonMobil’s Global Outlook shows H2 based fuels increasing dramatically by 2050 to > 10 quadrillion BTUs, primarily in the transportation and industrial sectors. Hydrogen can be produced by electrolysis of water, so-called green hydrogen, but this is not currently cost-competitive with other forms of hydrogen such as gray hydrogen (from steam reforming of methane, the dominant industrial process for hydrogen production today) or blue hydrogen (from steam reforming of methane plus carbon capture and sequestration) [21]. Opportunities for catalysis research to play a role in the production of hydrogen exist. The widespread adoption of proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWE) is hindered by the use of extremely scarce precious metals used as a catalyst for the oxygen evolution anode operating in a highly acidic environment. Electrocatalysts have primarily used Ir and Ru-based materials, their oxides and alloys [22]. Iridium recycling and a reduction in Ir utilization from ∼1–3 mgIr/cm2 to ∼0.1 mgIr/cm2 or less will be required in the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) to avoid global iridium supply limiting capacity expansion of PEMWE [23]. To achieve these goals, a greater research focus should be placed on increasing catalyst stability and synthesizing the preferred catalytic sites at low Ir loadings. However, even if the development of low Ir MEAs is achieved, this still does not mitigate the need for the vast amounts of renewable electrons needed to operate these electrolyzers to enable green hydrogen production in large quantities and at cost competitive prices. Other routes to hydrogen production being explored include steam reforming of organic compounds other than methane (e.g. methanol, ethanol etc.) and biomass conversion (e.g. through pyrolysis or gasification) [24]. These technologies are challenged by having lower feed H/C ratios than methane, and do not solve the problem of how to reject the carbon and oxygen in the feedstock in an environmentally friendly way. In addition, catalyst deactivation for these processes is a challenge and technological breakthroughs would be required to make such processes commercially interesting. 3.3 Biofuels Biofuels, or lower GHG emission fuels, are projected by ExxonMobil’s Global Outlook to increase ∼4X through 2050 [14]. For aviation in particular, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) demand is forecasted to increase significantly in line with the industries ambition to lower GHG emissions. For heavy duty commercial transportation, biodiesel and renewable diesel are forecasted to continue to be regulated as a transition fuels. Biodiesel is produced from biologically derived oils and lipids through transesterification of long chained fatty acids using homogenous or heterogeneous catalysts to produce mono-alkyl esters. Renewable diesel is produced via hydrotreating and dewaxing of fats and oils such as soybean or canola oil to make a product that is chemically similar to diesel derived from crude oil. Production of renewable diesel uses heterogeneous catalysts for both the hydrodeoxygenation step and the isomerization step require to meet product quality [25]. To reach the volumes of lower emission fuels needed by 2050, alternative technologies using feedstocks beyond first generation bio-derived fats and oils will be needed. Second generation biofuels derived from agricultural waste or woody biomass for example, can be converted into precursors for biofuel production through conversion technologies. These technologies include gasification, pyrolysis and fermentation that breaks down the cellulose, hemi-cellulose and lignin into molecules that need further conversion into the gasoline, jet and diesel molecules which fuel the engines of the modern economy. For these conversion and upgrading steps, catalytic technologies will play a key role, as indicated in Fig. 8. There are many challenges that will need to be overcome to enable the large-scale production of biofuels. One key challenge is associated with feedstock logistics. Feedstocks such as agricultural waste and woody biomass are not transportable through the existing infrastructure network of pipes and tankers that was designed to move liquids and gases. Prior to transportation via trucks, rail cars and barges, these solid feedstocks need to be harvested and collected, all of which use energy. In order to be fed into a conversion reactor, the feedstock may need to be conveyed, chopped, dried, and ground, all processes requiring energy. Consider a process using 2.5 MTA of woody biomass as a feedstock. If we use loblolly pine (Pinus taeda L.), a commonly found tree in the southeastern United States, as a representative woody biomass, the harvested wood will have an average moisture content of 48–56 %, depending on the location and age of the tree [26]. Let us assume that transportation is via combination trucks with a tractor pulling a 53’ trailer (semi-truck) weighing 35,000 lbs unloaded. The U.S. Federal Gross Vehicle Weight limit on the Interstate Highway system is 80,000 lbs, leaving a maximum cargo of 45,000 lbs (20 metric tons) that can be carried in the trailer [27]. To transport 6850 tons per day (tpd) of loblolly pine, one would need 342 trucks/day which translates to one truck every 4.2 min. (If the density of the biomass being transported falls below ∼10.7 lbs/ft3, the truck becomes volume limited, assuming a trailer that is 102” wide and 110” inside height which would require >342 trucks/day to transport 6850 tons/day.) Using an average tree diameter at breast height (4.5’) of 12”, the weight of the tree would be ∼1500 lbs [28] and one would need to harvest ∼10,000 trees/day or 7 trees/min every day of the year to get 2.5 MTA of wood. Ignoring the challenges of harvesting these many trees and loading and unloading these trucks at the frequency required, the question arises as to how much biofuel can one make from this process using 2.5 MTA of pine as a feedstock. If this feedstock (dried to 8 % moisture) is then fed to a fast pyrolysis auger reactor, the yield of bio-oil is likely in the range 49–55 % [29]. This will therefore yield 1,925 tons/day of bio-oil, or ∼10 kbd of bio-oil, using a density of 1.19 g/cm3 [29]. Unfortunately, this bio-oil is not useable as a fuel and needs further upgrading. One approach to upgrading the bio-oil is to co-process it in an FCC together with crude oil derived VGO [30]. This enables the rejection of the large oxygen content in the bio-oil as CO, CO2 and H2O. One experimentally derived FCC carbon efficiency for converting bio-carbon into liquid products was 30 % [30]. If we assume that the bio-carbon converts to gasoline in the FCC, one can estimate that the 10 kbd of bio-oil will produce 3.5 kbd of fuel. The overall yield of the process (weight of fuel produced / weight of harvested tree) is therefore only 6.1 %. For perspective, in 2024, the U.S. produced 8,945 kbd of finished motor gasoline [19]. The 3.5 kbd of gasoline produced from 2.5 MTA of woody biomass is therefore the equivalent of 0.04 % of the 2024 US motor gasoline production. Today, electric vehicles are a relatively small percentage of global car sales but are projected to exceed 50 % by 2050, as shown in Fig. 9. Even if 50 % of new car sales in 2050 are powered by alternative drive trains, the world’s total global light-duty fleet will not exceed 50 % due to the 10–15 year lag in turning over fleet vehicles. There will be hundreds of millions of ICE vehicles on the road in 2040 that will still be consuming gasoline in 2050. If we assume that the trend in the US follows the global trend, then we can estimate that 2.5 MTA of biomass produced by harvesting 10,000 acres at 400 trees/acre per year will not produce more than 0.1 % of the 2050 US gasoline demand. Typically, fast pyrolysis is conducted with sand as the heat transfer medium but some research has explored catalytic fast pyrolysis as a mechanism to improve the quality of the bio oil produced by such processes [31]. However, the drawback of such an approach is a decrease in yield of bio-oil with an increase in the production of water, CO and CO2 [32] with the catalyst promoting the deoxygenation reactions. This decrease in bio-oil yield will likely limit the commercialization of catalytic fast pyrolysis as a meaningful route to the production of biofuels but may find some application in the production of chemicals such as aromatics. 3.4 Improvements to existing catalytic processes From the discussion above, catalysis can and will play a role as an enabler for the third energy transition but likely will not be as significant as the role played by catalysis in the second energy transition. However, there are many other opportunities where improvements to existing catalytic processes can reduce the energy needed to operate such processes and hence reduce GHG emissions. Since almost all catalytic reactions require heat to initiate, any new catalyst that enables the reaction to occur at a lower temperature will provide an advantage. As an example, consider the production of paraxylene from mixed xylenes, as shown in Fig. 10. The mixed xylenes could be sourced from a reformer on a refinery or could be from a catalytic pyrolysis unit targeting aromatics. The xylene loop is energy intensive and inefficient due to the equilibrium constraint of ∼24 % paraxylene. As a result of this constraint, approximately 3 xylene molecules are recycled for every 1 paraxylene recovered from the loop. Since the paraxylene recovery is done from the liquid phase at low temperature using either a simulated moving bed or crystallization and the distillation and vapor phase isomerization reaction are done at high temperatures, there are 4 phase changes with heat-ups and cool-downs required as the xylene molecules spin around this loop. Consequently, the xylene loop consumes significantly more energy than any other part of a typical aromatics plant [33]. The loop traffic is highly sensitive to the paraxylene concentration in the recycle, so a process operating with reduced xylene recycle needs less energy to operate (and increases capacity.) The development of a liquid phase xylene isomerization (LPI) process spanned decades of research. A new LPI process has been operated commercially since 2015 [34] which was enabled by advances in the preparation and formulation of high activity zeolites [35]. A typical flowsheet for an LPI flowsheet is shown in Fig. 11, where a low temperature, liquid phase reactor takes para depleted xylenes from the paraxylene recovery unit and re-equilibrates the xylenes to 24 % para content before returning them to the xylene splitter. The energy savings come from both the liquid phase reaction taking place at lower temperature as well as the reduction in molecular traffic through the energy intensive xylene loop operating with a vapor phase isomerization reactor (XyMax-2 in this flowsheet). This LPI process has been operating at ExxonMobil’s Rotterdam facility since January 2015 [33] which resulted in a 9 % reduction in energy use for the overall loop operation. This reduction in energy use for this one unit is equivalent to the energy used by 30,000 Dutch homes and the CO2 reduction associated with this energy savings is the equivalent of removing 23,000 ICE vehicles from Dutch roads [36]. Another example illustrating this point is the introduction of the liquid phase ExxonMobil-Badger EBMax process in 1995 [37]. Prior to the development of this process, the most widely used zeolitic ethylbenzene process was the ExxonMobil-Badger vapor phase process, first introduced in 1980, that used ZSM-5 to catalyze the alkylation of benzene with ethylene at temperatures ranging from 370 to 420°C. Under these conditions, cycle lengths were poor (∼60 days) until the introduction of second and third generation processes in 1986 and 1991, respectively, increased cycle lengths to more than 1 year. The EBMax process, shown schematically in Fig. 12, is a liquid phase ethylbenzene process based on the MCM-22 (MWW) family of zeolites that catalyzes the alkylation reaction at temperatures from 220 to 250°C [38]. Cycle lengths in excess of 3 years have been achieved commercially allowing for reduced catalyst regeneration. The high monoalkylate selectivity of the MCM-22 family of zeolites when compared to other large pore zeolites such as beta and Y allow for the EBMax process to operate at low feed ratios of benzene to ethylene (B:E). Lower B:E reduces the benzene circulation rate which improves the efficiency of the process and reduces traffic through the benzene recovery column which further reduces the energy required [37]. In addition to developing new catalytic processes operating at lower temperatures, improvements to the stability of existing catalysts can also contribute towards lowering GHG emissions. As catalysts deactivate over time in commercial reactors, the decreased catalytic activity needs to be offset by increasing the reactor temperature which comes at a cost of increased energy consumption and increased GHG emissions, assuming the heat input comes from the combustion of natural gas in a furnace. In addition, at end of life, spent catalysts are often regenerated which produces GHG emissions both from the burning of natural gas to heat the air to the temperature needed to initiate combustion of the coke as well as from the oxidation of the carbon in the coke. Any improvements to the stability of heterogeneous catalysts or the reduction in coke selectivity of catalyzed reactions will help in reducing the energy consumed to produce the products that support our modern lifestyle. An example of a catalytic reaction with high coke selectivity is the conversion of methanol over molecular sieves. Small pore silicoaluminophosphate molecular sieves, for example SAPO-34, are well known to be effective for the conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO), predominately ethylene and propylene [39,40]. Small pore molecular sieves tend to trap aromatic molecules in their cages, resulting in high coke selectivities and shorter catalyst lifetimes. As a result of the rapid deactivation of the small pore molecular sieves used for MTO processes, fluid bed reactors with continuous catalyst regeneration are required. Reducing the coke selectivity of small pore molecular sieves in methanol conversion reactions would enable a reduction in size of the catalyst regenerator in a fluid bed system and reduce the amount of carbon entering the process as methanol that gets lost as CO2 from the regenerator. Work by ExxonMobil starting in 2001 showed that the use of basic metal oxide co-catalysts significantly reduces the coke selectivity in methanol conversion reactions such as MTO. (This effect was confirmed 16 years later by academic studies [41].) These basic metal oxides may be Group 3 oxides, e.g. Y2O3, Group 4 Oxides, e.g. ZrO2, Group 2 Oxides, e.g. MgO, or hydrotalcite [42,43]. The presence of these basic oxides in a physical mixture with a molecular sieve catalyst leads to a significant increase of up to 500 % in catalyst lifetime, defined as the amount of methanol converted per gram of molecular sieve before methanol conversion declines to 10 %, as indicated in Fig. 13. These basic metal oxide co-catalysts are present in the reactor as a physical mixture together with the acidic molecular sieve catalyst which does the methanol conversion reaction inside the pores, begging the question of how the co-catalyst has this ability to impact the coke selectivity of a reaction occurring on another particle some distance away. Clearly, the co-catalyst cannot impact the chemistry occurring in the cage of the molecular sieve unless it is intercepting an intermediate molecule that facilitates the formation of coke. It is proposed that formaldehyde, formed by the dehydrogenation of methanol and catalyzed by the walls of the reactor or any heated metal surface between the vaporizer and the reactor, is one of the main species promoting the formation of coke. This was illustrated by feeding methanol/formaldehyde mixtures over EMM-2 (a silicoaluminophosphate molecular sieve comprising at least one intergrown form of molecular sieves having AEI and CHA framework types and prepared as described in US Patent 6,812,372 [44]) at 500°C, 25 psig and WHSV = 100 h−1. As shown in Fig. 14, the catalyst lifetime deceases with increasing formaldehyde concentration, with coke selectivity increasing with an increase in formaldehyde concentration. To illustrate the functionality of the basic metal oxide co-catalyst, the same set of methanol/formaldehyde mixtures were fed to a reactor containing a EMM-2:Y2O3 physical mixture with the results plotted in Fig. 15. With formaldehyde as a co-feed the catalyst lifetime of ∼25 g/g was still in excess of the typical lifetime of ∼15 g/g seen with a pure methanol feed and no co-catalyst, as seen in Fig. 13. This data suggests that the presence of the yttria co-catalyst in the reactor bed has negated the deleterious impact of formaldehyde on catalyst lifetime. It was therefore proposed that basic metal oxide co-catalysts, e.g. Y2O3, reduce the formaldehyde to coke reaction mechanism by providing an alternative disposition pathway for the formaldehyde. One possible pathway to eliminate formaldehyde involves the Cannizzaro reaction, a chemical reaction that involves the base-induced disproportionation of an aldehyde lacking a hydrogen atom in the alpha position [45]. In the presence of a base, the aqueous Cannizzaro reaction of formaldehyde with itself is represented in Eq. 5. (5) 2 HCHO → + H 2 O CHOOH + C H 3 OH However, in the heterogeneous gas-phase environment of an MTO reactor containing a basic metal oxide co-catalyst, free formic acid is not anticipated to form via Eq. (5) and escape from the surface of the metal oxide. It is anticipated that the reaction of formaldehyde via a mechanistic route analogous to the Cannizzaro reaction will lead to the simultaneous formation of surface formates and methoxide species, as has been demonstrated on model MgO surfaces [46]. In this reaction, the carbonyl carbon of an adsorbed formaldehyde would attach to a surface base site on the yttria, forming a surface dioxymethylene intermediate. The bond between the hydrogen and the carbonyl carbon would be weakened by the transfer of electron density from the surface oxygen to the carbonyl carbon, allowing a neighboring adsorbed formaldehyde molecule to accommodate this hydride, forming a surface methoxide group. This reaction can be represented by Eq. (6). (6) Image 1 The surface formate formed by the Cannizzaro type reaction in Eq. (6) then undergoes decomposition to carbon oxides via Eq. (7) and/or Eq. (8). (7) 2 HCHO ( g ) → Basic Catalyst C H 3 OH ( g ) + CO ( g ) (8) 2 HCHO ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) → Basic Catalyst C H 3 OH ( g ) + C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 g The basic metal oxide co-catalyst thereby provides an alternative disposition pathway where formaldehyde is converted back into methanol with the production of H2, CO or CO2 as byproducts. This small amount of CO/CO2 is significantly less than that produced by the combustion of coke (trapped aromatic rings) leading to a lower CO2 footprint for a methanol conversion process. Given that many methanol to jet (MTJ) processes currently under development rely on the conversion of green methanol or e-methanol to olefins as an intermediate for olefin oligomerization reactions for the production of sustainable aviation fuels, incorporation of catalyst advancements to lower coke selectivity will further lower the carbon intensity of such processes. While not every catalytic process currently used in refining and chemical production facilities is amenable to the improvements described above, it would be a worthwhile pivot for the catalysis community to move away from a mindset of “the catalyst deactivates and we will just manage this through catalyst rejuvenation” to “the catalyst deactivates and we should understand why and develop strategies to mitigate this deactivation.” Catalyst stability is poorly understood at a fundamental level but advances in catalyst productivity and lifetime would have important benefits for industry practitioners [47]. 4 Impact of the third energy transition on catalysis Section 3 has focused on how catalysis could impact the third energy transition, but another question that should be asked is how the third energy transition could impact catalysis. The third energy transition is really enabled by metals, especially rare earth metals, that are needed for the production of batteries, wind turbines and solar photovoltaic panels [48]. As the third energy transition progresses, the world will need increasing amounts of metals that need to be mined from the earth’s crust for energy transition uses and this could potentially lead to increasing challenges in obtaining the metals needed for catalyst manufacture [49]. It has been estimated that the next generation of humans will mine more metal from the earth’s crust than all preceding generations combined [50]. Fig. 16 shows the lifespan of viable reserves of key metals with some catalytically important metals highlighted in red. The potential for future supply constraints exists and catalysis researchers need to adopt a mindset of developing catalysts that use the lowest amount of metal needed for the chemistry. This will also necessitate development of manufacturing techniques that enable the commercial production of such catalysts which effectively use the available metal surfaces. Increased levels of metals recovery from spent catalysts will also likely become more important and catalysts should be developed with metals reclamation in mind. In addition to future supply constraints, the metals used in catalysis are not immune to potential supply/price disruptions. As an example, the 2011 price spikes in rare earth oxides (REO), specifically lanthanum and cerium oxide, as shown in Fig. 17, led to a doubling of FCC catalyst costs. The 2011 price spikes were driven by drastic reductions in export quotas of rare earth oxides by China, the world’s dominant supplier of these materials. This resulted in a scramble by FCC catalyst manufacturers to bring low REO catalysts to the market. While this price spike in rare earth oxides was short lived, it does illustrate that the catalyst market is not immune to global political and economic events. 5 Conclusions The third energy transition is viewed by many to be underway, but it will differ in consequences from the first and second energy transitions which fundamentally transformed the way that mankind uses energy. Energy sources underpinning the third energy transition will probably be considered additive to the energy resource base rather than total replacements for existing sources of energy. The world needs a lot of energy, approximately 1 quadrillion BTUs (= 1.055 exajoules) every 14.6 h, and supplying that energy in a way that meets the world’s needs AND lowers emissions is a key challenge facing society. Solving this “AND” equation will not be done in isolation by industry, academia or national labs but will require a concerted effort and partnership between all parties. The catalysis community will be required to make strategic choices informed by the scale of the problems that need to be solved. It is this author’s hope that a more collaborative research environment can be created between all parties in the catalysis community to ensure that our research priorities are appropriately directed to make best use of our resources. This will position catalysis as a science to make the most meaningful contributions to the third energy transition. Doron Levin is the Materials and Applied Chemistry Chief Scientist for ExxonMobil Technology and Engineering Company. Over the course of his career spanning 28 years to date, Doron has discovered, developed and commercialized many catalytic technologies for the production of chemicals and clean fuels. Examples of such commercialized technologies include the Nebula and Celestia bulk hydrotreating catalysts, and zeolite-based catalysts for liquid phase xylene isomerization, heavy aromatics transalkylation, and benzene alkylation for production of ethylbenzene and cumene. Doron has over 80 US patents with many patent families filed worldwide. Doron is the recipient of numerous ExxonMobil awards as well as the Gordon E. Moore Medal from the Society of Chemical Industry. He has a PhD in Chemical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

coredata.dc:description: According to the International Energy Forum [1], the third energy transition is underway. However, it will differ in consequences from the first and second energy transitions which transformed the way that mankind uses energy. The third energy transition is primarily additive to the energy resource base rather than a substantial replacement for existing sources of energy. The world needs a lot of energy, approximately 1 quadrillion BTUs (= 1.055 exajoules) every 14.6 h, and supplying that energy in a way that meets the world’s needs and lowers emissions is the key challenge facing society. While the second energy transition was in part enabled by and dependent on advances in catalysis, it is unclear what the impact of catalysis will be on the third energy transition which is driven primarily by the movement of electrons rather than transformation of molecules. This perspective article attempts to provide some thoughts and insights in addressing this question.
coredata.dc:title: Is catalysis an enabler for the third energy transition?
